CHAPTER IV. The views of Tertullian.

SUcH was the state of parties in the Christian Church, when Tertullian came forward to answer the question as to conformity or non-conformity. He* had no doubt which side to espouse. He had, it appears, as a heathen, enthusiastically delighted in heathen pleasure, and as a Christian, he enthusiastically abhorred them1. What he most feared was double-mindedness, and the confusion of light and darkness. He had little inclination to trace out principles shared in common by Christian and Gen- tile.
